signature.name: DROID File Collection File
signature.note: <FileCollection>â€¦<DROIDVersion> elements. {0-50} < F I l e C o l l e c t I o n {0-100} < D R O I D V e r s I o n > {1-10} < / D R O I D V e r s I o n > - NB. The signature byte sequence is currently massaged to steer around the known PRONOM bug in the are of the left fragment matching when the longest fragment is not nearest BOF. The last fragment in the BOF byte sequence has been shortened by 2 bytes to ensure that the first fragment is the longest. This abbreviation does not reduce the overall signature strength too much and so will hopefully not result in any false positive identification. When the PRONOM bug has been fixed, "0D0A" should be appended to the BOF byte sequence and this note reduced.

signature.name: DROID Signature File
signature.note: <FFSignatureFile> element - {0-50} F F S I g n a t u r e F I l e {0-100} V e r s I o n =

signature.name: Windows Media Video
signature.note: Header Object + Stream Properties Object (stream type = Video Stream) with WMV Compression ID

signature.name: MPEG-1 Audio Layer 3 with ID3v2 Tag
signature.note: Regularly-spaced frame headers should always be discoverable near EOF. An ID3v1 tag of up to 355 bytes may be present at EOF. NB. The signature byte sequence is currently massaged to steer around the known PRONOM bug in the area of right fragment matching when the longest fragment is not nearest EOF. A fragment of three null bytes has been appended to the signature to ensure it's the longest. These null bytes appear to be always present so will hopefully not cause any valid MP3 file to fail identification. When the PRONOM bug has been fixed, the "FFFB{10-50}000000{37-1782}" at the end of the byte sequence should be replaced by "FFFB(47-1795)" and this note curtailed. The BOF byte sequence represents the MP3 ID3 tag.

signature.name: MPEG-2 Audio Layer 3 with ID3v2 Tag
signature.note: Regularly-spaced frame headers should always be discoverable near EOF. An ID3v1 tag of up to 355 bytes may be present at EOF. NB. The signature byte sequence is currently massaged to steer around the known PRONOM bug in the area of right fragment matching when the longest fragment is not nearest EOF. A fragment of three null bytes has been appended to the signature to ensure it's the longest. These null bytes appear to be always present so will hopefully not cause any valid MP3 file to fail identification. When the PRONOM bug has been fixed, the "FFF3{10-50}000000{37-1782}" at the end of the byte sequence should be replaced by "FFF3(47-1795)" and this note curtailed. The BOF byte sequence represents the MP3 ID3 tag.

signature.name: MPEG-1 Audio Layer 3 with ID3v2 Tag (protected)
signature.note: Regularly-spaced frame headers should always be discoverable near EOF. Header has CRC bit off to indicate protected. An ID3v1 tag of up to 355 bytes may be present at EOF. NB. The signature byte sequence is currently massaged to steer around the known PRONOM bug in the area of right fragment matching when the longest fragment is not nearest EOF. A fragment of three null bytes has been appended to the signature to ensure it's the longest. These null bytes appear to be always present so will hopefully not cause any valid MP3 file to fail identification. When the PRONOM bug has been fixed, the "FFFA{10-50}000000{37-1782}" at the end of the byte sequence should be replaced by "FFFA(47-1795)" and this note curtailed. The BOF byte sequence represents the MP3 ID3 tag.

signature.name: MPEG-2 Audio Layer 3 with ID3v2 Tag (protected)
signature.note: Regularly-spaced frame headers should always be discoverable near EOF. Header has CRC bit off to indicate protected. An ID3v1 tag of up to 355 bytes may be present at EOF. NB. The signature byte sequence is currently massaged to steer around the known PRONOM bug in the area of right fragment matching when the longest fragment is not nearest EOF. A fragment of three null bytes has been appended to the signature to ensure it's the longest. These null bytes appear to be always present so will hopefully not cause any valid MP3 file to fail identification. When the PRONOM bug has been fixed, the "FFF2{10-50}000000{37-1782}" at the end of the byte sequence should be replaced by "FFF2(47-1795)" and this note curtailed. The BOF byte sequence represents the MP3 ID3 tag.

signature.name: MPEG-1 Audio Layer 3 without ID3v2 Tag
signature.note: Regularly-spaced frame headers should always be discoverable starting at BOF.

signature.name: MPEG-2 Audio Layer 3 without ID3v2 Tag
signature.note: Regularly-spaced frame headers should always be discoverable starting at BOF.

signature.name: MPEG-1 Audio Layer 3 without ID3v2 Tag (protected)
signature.note: Regularly-spaced frame headers should always be discoverable starting at BOF with each header having CRC bit set off to indicate file is protected.

signature.name: MPEG-2 Audio Layer 3 without ID3v2 Tag (protected)
signature.note: Regularly-spaced frame headers should always be discoverable starting at BOF with each header having CRC bit set off to indicate file is protected.

signature.name: PrimeOCR 3.0
signature.note: Initial bytes of PrimeOCR output format represent Version,Format,Confidence and are represented in binary as ASCII at the beginning of the *.pro format. The value 430,0,450, represent version 4.3 of the format, custom word flag representing format and a confidence of 850 (PrimeOCR confidence * 100). The hex representation of this is 34 33 30 2C 30 2C 34 35 30 2C (we include the final signature represented in the format to create the unique signature). If version 4.3 is represented as 34 33 30 (ascii), version 4.2 for example is represented as 34 32 30, 3.8 as 33 38 39.

signature.name: PrimeOCR 3.8
signature.note: Initial bytes of PrimeOCR output format represent Version,Format,Confidence and are represented in binary as ASCII at the beginning of the *.pro format. The value 430,0,450, represent version 4.3 of the format, custom word flag representing format and a confidence of 850 (PrimeOCR confidence * 100). The hex representation of this is 34 33 30 2C 30 2C 34 35 30 2C (we include the final signature represented in the format to create the unique signature). If version 4.3 is represented as 34 33 30 (ascii), version 4.2 for example is represented as 34 32 30, 3.8 as 33 38 39.

signature.name: PrimeOCR 3.9
signature.note: Initial bytes of PrimeOCR output format represent Version,Format,Confidence and are represented in binary as ASCII at the beginning of the *.pro format. The value 430,0,450, represent version 4.3 of the format, custom word flag representing format and a confidence of 850 (PrimeOCR confidence * 100). The hex representation of this is 34 33 30 2C 30 2C 34 35 30 2C (we include the final signature represented in the format to create the unique signature). If version 4.3 is represented as 34 33 30 (ascii), version 4.2 for example is represented as 34 32 30, 3.8 as 33 38 39.

signature.name: PrimeOCR 4.0
signature.note: Initial bytes of PrimeOCR output format represent Version,Format,Confidence and are represented in binary as ASCII at the beginning of the *.pro format. The value 430,0,450, represent version 4.3 of the format, custom word flag representing format and a confidence of 850 (PrimeOCR confidence * 100). The hex representation of this is 34 33 30 2C 30 2C 34 35 30 2C (we include the final signature represented in the format to create the unique signature). If version 4.3 is represented as 34 33 30 (ascii), version 4.2 for example is represented as 34 32 30, 3.8 as 33 38 39.

signature.name: PrimeOCR 4.2
signature.note: Initial bytes of PrimeOCR output format represent Version,Format,Confidence and are represented in binary as ASCII at the beginning of the *.pro format. The value 430,0,450, represent version 4.3 of the format, custom word flag representing format and a confidence of 850 (PrimeOCR confidence * 100). The hex representation of this is 34 33 30 2C 30 2C 34 35 30 2C (we include the final signature represented in the format to create the unique signature). If version 4.3 is represented as 34 33 30 (ascii), version 4.2 for example is represented as 34 32 30, 3.8 as 33 38 39.

signature.name: PrimeOCR 4.3
signature.note: Initial bytes of PrimeOCR output format represent Version,Format,Confidence and are represented in binary as ASCII at the beginning of the *.pro format. The value 430,0,450, represent version 4.3 of the format, custom word flag representing format and a confidence of 850 (PrimeOCR confidence * 100). The hex representation of this is 34 33 30 2C 30 2C 34 35 30 2C (we include the final signature represented in the format to create the unique signature). If version 4.3 is represented as 34 33 30 (ascii), version 4.2 for example is represented as 34 32 30, 3.8 as 33 38 39.

signature.name: Microsoft Office Open XML
signature.note: Signature represents a combination of OOXML specific bytes and a standard ZIP signature (taken verbatim from Zip format sig). Last two bytes of this signature represents a Microsoft Open Packaging growth hint which indentifies this as one of three OOXML document types so far.

signature.name: Outlook Express Mail Message
signature.note: Version of ARPA Internet Text Message. ASCII Characters, X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2900.3350 and including the two CRLF that terminate the line in the eml header. Signature may be too prescriptive and will need improving with more eml format testing.

signature.name: Acrobat PDF/A
signature.note: Describes a signature for the PDF/A format. Identifies the byte sequence which equals - xmlns:pdfaid="http://www.aiim.org/pdfa/ns/id/ which is the PDF/A identification namespace within the PDF/A meta-data. This signature identifies PDF/A formats generically. Further "characterization" byte sequence records can be added to identify subsets, i.e. PDF/A-1a or PDF/A-1b by identifying the <pdfaid:part> bytes after this initial sequence. See ISO 19005-1:2005 and Technical Corrigendum 1 for further information.

signature.name: HTML pre-2.0
signature.note: Signature for pre-2.0 HTML, or non-valid HTML (no DOCTYPE declaration). EOF character sequence: </(HTML|html|BODY|body)>{0-1024}

signature.name: HTML 2.0
signature.note: With DOCTYPE declaration for 2.0. Single byte sequence, BOF character sequence: {0-1024}<!(DOCTYPE|doctype) (HTML|html) (PUBLIC/public) "-//{1-16}//(DTD|dtd) {0-64}(HTML|html) 2.0

signature.name: HTML 3.2
signature.note: With DOCTYPE declaration of 3.2. Single byte sequence. BOF character sequence: {0-1024}<!(DOCTYPE|doctype) (HTML|html) (PUBLIC/public) "-//{1-16}//(DTD|dtd) {0-64}(HTML|html) 3.2

signature.name: HTML 4.0
signature.note: With DOCTYPE declaration of 4.0. Single byte sequence. BOF character sequence: {0-1024}<!(DOCTYPE|doctype) (HTML|html) (PUBLIC/public) "-//{1-16}//(DTD|dtd) {0-64}(HTML|html) 4.(0 |0/)

signature.name: RealAudio Metafile
signature.note: Header

signature.name: ESRI Arc/View ShapeFile
signature.note: 100-byte header (file code, version), then first record number. | Magic No. (4 bytes) | Unused (20 bytes) | File Length (4 bytes) | Version (1000 (decimal), little endian - 4 bytes) | Other - (68 bytes) | First Record No. (4 bytes) |

signature.name: MS Access 95
signature.note: Jet 3 DB header plus variably-positioned AccessVersion 06. Two byte sequences. Sequence one character sequence, Standard Jet DB. Sequence two character sequence AccessVersion{0-1024}06.[0:9][0:9]

signature.name: MS Access 97
signature.note: Jet 3 DB header plus variably-positioned AccessVersion 07. Two byte sequences. Sequence one character sequence, Standard Jet DB. Sequence two character sequence AccessVersion{1-1024}07.[0:9][0:9]

signature.name: MS Access 2000
signature.note: Jet 4 DB header plus variably-positioned AccessVersion 08. Two byte sequences. First byte sequence character sequence, Standard Jet DB. Second byte sequence character sequence, A c c e s s V e r s I o n{0-2048} 0 8 . [0:9] [0:9]

signature.name: MS Access 2002/3
signature.note: Jet 4 DB header plus variably-positioned AccessVersion 09. Two byte sequences. First byte sequence character sequence, Standard Jet DB. Second byte sequence character sequence, A c c e s s V e r s I o n{0-2048} 0 9 . [0:9] [0:9]

signature.name: Personal Storage Table *.pst (ANSI)
signature.note: Byte analysis completed in http://downloads.sourceforge.net/libpff/Personal_Foler_File_Format.pdf (Personal Folder File (PFF) File Format Specification) and sequence confirmed by research completed in http://www.five-ten-sg.com/libpst/rn01re06.html. PST file header, 24 bytes in total.

signature.name: Personal Storage Table *.pst (Unicode)
signature.note: Byte analysis completed in http://downloads.sourceforge.net/libpff/Personal_Foler_File_Format.pdf (Personal Folder File (PFF) File Format Specification) and sequence confirmed by research completed in http://www.five-ten-sg.com/libpst/rn01re06.html. PST file header, 24 bytes in total.

signature.name: ZIP format
signature.note: Local file header at BOF + central file header and end of central directory near EOF. NB. The signature byte sequence is currently massaged to steer around the known PRONOM bug in the area of right fragment matching when the kongest fragment is not nearest EOF. The first fragment in the EOF byte sequence has been shortened by 1 byte to ensure that the subsequent fragment is the longest. This abbreviation does not reduce the overall signature strength too much and so will hopefully not result in any false pisitive identification. When the PRONOM bug has been fixed, the "504B01" at the start of the EOF byte sequence should be extended to "504B0102", and this note reduced.

signature.name: TAR (Tape Archive)
signature.note: TAR specification has a 256 byte header which includes 6 octal numbers which may be space or null terminated, may have leading spaces or zeros, and may vary in position by one byte, all depending on which of the many flavours the format follows. The above signature was tested on varied TAR files off the internet and the unknown files in digital preservation successfully.

signature.name: GZIP format
signature.note: Member header ID1 and ID2 fields

signature.name: FLV 1
signature.note: Header only

signature.name: FITS
signature.note: Header (SIMPLE, BITPIX and NAXIS card images)

signature.name: QuickTime 1
signature.note: Movie atom (moov) + movie header atom (mvhd)

signature.name: Quicktime 2
signature.note: Movie data atom (mdat) + movie atom (moov) + movie header atom (mvhd)

signature.name: Quicktime 3
signature.note: Movie atom (moov) + compressed movie atom (cmov) + data compression atom (dcom)

signature.name: Quicktime 4
signature.note: Movie data atom (mdat) + movie atom (moov) + compressed movie atom (cmov) + data compression atom (dcom)

signature.name: QuickTime 5
signature.note: Placeholder atom (wide) + movie data atom (mdat) + movie atom (moov) + movie header atom (mvhd)

signature.name: QuickTime 6
signature.note: Placeholder atom (wide) + movie data atom (mdat) + movie atom (moov) + compressed movie atom (cmov) + data compression atom (dcom)

signature.name: QuickTime
signature.note: Atoms: mdat, cmov, moov, ftyp, pnot, wide, skip, free, junk, or pict

signature.name: MPEG-1/2 Video Generic
signature.note: Pack Header start code + System Header start code

signature.name: MPEG-1/2 Video Generic
signature.note: Pack Header start code + System Header start code

signature.name: JAR format
signature.note: Local file header + manifest + end of central directory. Signature consists of two byte sequences, a BOF sequence and EOF sequence. BOF character sequence: PK..*META-INF/MANIFEST.MF, EOF character sequence: PK..

signature.name: Java Compiled Object Code
signature.note: Header

signature.name: Microsoft Windows Shortcut
signature.note: Reference to format: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd871305(PROT.10).aspx. Byte values five to eight seem to need to be reversed (little-endian ordering) from the suggested ordering in the specification. Ambiguity in the specification means this ordering may or may not be expected.

signature.name: Outlook Message Format
signature.note: Compound document header + IPM.Note + recip_version stream header

signature.name: 3DM 4
signature.note: Header with version no.

signature.name: 3DM 1
signature.note: Header with version no.

signature.name: 3DM 2
signature.note: Header with version no.

signature.name: 3DM 3
signature.note: Header with version no.

signature.name: WordPerfect for Windows 6.x - 12
signature.note: Also known as Corel WordPerfect. Major and minor version fields are the main variants between 6.x and 12 formats (The last two bytes in this signature). The major version is the same for 6.x through to 12 documents - 2. The minor version byte for a 9 non-compound file created in WPWin 8.0 is 1. The minor version for a 9 compound file created in WPWin 8.0. Is 2.

signature.name: Microsoft Windows URL
signature.note: Signature - 5B 49 6E 74 65 72 6E 65 74 53 68 6F 72 74 63 75 74 5D - ASCII - [InternetShortcut] may further be ammended by two bytes 0x0D 0x0A [CR LF / Carriage Return, Line Feed] at the end of the signature if required. Further, the initial 18 byte sequence may suffer regional differences, additional byte sequences may be required to identify these also.

signature.name: MS Access 2.0
signature.note: DB header plus variably-positioned AccessVersion 02. Looking primarily for a character sequence that has been found to exist reliably. Character sequence in the second byte sequence is: AccessVersion{0-32}02.[0:9][0:9]

signature.name: PowerPoint 4.0
signature.note: Compound document header + PowerPoint Document user stream + version number (pp40)

signature.name: PostScript DSC 1.0
signature.note: PostScript DSC header version comment + EOF comment
